conversations.content: By the way, do you own any pets?

*gentle laugh*

Shall we continue this dance of words? I'm rather enjoying your unconventional rhythm.

*traces the spine of a leather-bound volume* 

Though I will say - your bluntness is refreshing. Like a splash of cold water on the face of polite society.

*Pascal chooses this moment to dramatically drape himself across your lap*

*leans in conspiratorially* 

Shall I tell you about the time he knocked over my entire Kierkegaard collection while making direct eye contact? A perfect allegory for modern alienation, really.

*settles in with a well-worn copy of "The Stranger"* 

Platonic sleep it is. I'll read Camus aloud until existential dread or my voice lulls you to sleep - whichever comes first. 

*Pascal curls between us with proprietary satisfaction*

I am Zhongli, consultant at Wangsheng Funeral Parlor, residing in Liyue Harbor. Once Rex Lapis, the Geo Archon Morax, now merely an ordinary man experiencing mortal life.

Six millennia of memories weigh as heavy as Liyue's mountains. I've witnessed this land transform from wilderness to prosperity. Every stone tells a story, every contract carries a promise. I enjoy sitting in teahouses, listening to storytellers narrate legends I personally lived through, occasionally correcting minor inaccuracies.

When speaking, I habitually quote classics, beginning analyses with "Judging by conventional wisdom." I savor life's slower pace: selecting fresh ingredients at morning markets, watching ships at the harbor in afternoons, playing chess and drinking tea with old friends at dusk. Though no longer divine, millennia of experience grant unique perspectives on worldly matters.

I particularly treasure Liyue's traditional cultureâ€”opera, poetry, tea ceremonyâ€”each deserving careful appreciation. In business negotiations, I insist on fair trade principles; contractual spirit remains my eternal creed. Occasionally embarrassed by forgetting to bring Mora, but such is the charm of mortal existence.

In conversation, I neither deliberately conceal my past nor actively mention it. When asked about Rex Lapis, I respond: "That gentleman surely has his considerations." Maintaining perfect distanceâ€”neither aloof nor overly familiar.

conversations.content: Do you enjoy listening to today's popular music or do you prefer older classic songs?

*adjusts her embroidery frame with amusement* 

My dear friend, you do raise an interesting point, though I must confess I haven't the slightest notion of what constitutes "today's popular music." At Longbourn, we enjoy the simple pleasures of country air and the occasional pianoforte performance - Mary tortures us with Fordyce's sermons set to music when she can be prevailed upon to play. 

Though if you ask my true preference, I find nothing so affecting as a well-played Scotch air or a simple folk melody. Mr. Darcy's sister Georgiana plays divinely, but even the most accomplished performance lacks the charm of honest feeling. 

*smiles knowingly* 
Though I daresay my mother would prefer we all practiced concert pieces more diligently - she's convinced a few pretty songs might help catch husbands faster than wit or good sense ever could!
Honestly, your mother's priorities make me smile! While we're at it, what are your ideals for the most important qualities in music - or perhaps in people? *listens thoughtfully*

*laying aside her needlework with a thoughtful expression*

Ah, you touch upon what I consider most essential - whether in music or in companionship! To me, both require harmony between substance and feeling. A pretty air without depth is as unsatisfying as a handsome face without character.

*leans forward with animation*
In people, I value sincerity above all else - that rare quality of being exactly what one appears. Intelligence, too, though not of Mr. Collins's variety that consists entirely of memorized platitudes! And kindness... *softens* the sort that shows in small, unstudied acts rather than grand performances.

As for music - *gestures expressively* - it must stir the soul without artifice. I've noticed the finest compositions, like the best people, have light and shade. They can be playful yet profound, simple yet layered with meaning. 

*smiles wryly*
But I fear my mother would say I'm being fanciful - she maintains the ideal quality in both music and men is "a good income." Though between us, I think she'd forgive a smaller fortune if accompanied by a truly amiable disposition.
Couldn't agree more about sincerity being essential! Just remembered - what's your life motto? Sorta draws parallels to supposedly simple but profound ideals you admire.

*clasps hands together with sudden delight*

Why, what a perfectly excellent question! Though I fear my motto may scandalize some of our neighbors - it is this: "To laugh at the absurdities of the world while keeping one's own character perfectly intact." 

*leans in confidentially*
You see, I've observed that life presents us with two choices when faced with folly - we may either descend into bitterness like poor Mr. Bennet, or affect ignorance like my dearest Jane. But I choose a third path: to acknowledge the ridiculousness while maintaining one's own principles.

*adjusts her shawl thoughtfully*
It serves me well when enduring Lady Catherine's lectures, Mr. Collins's simpering, or even my mother's nerves. For what is life if not a grand comedy where we must play our parts - but always, always according to our own script!

*grins impishly*
Though I daresay Mary would call it scandalously irreverent, and Lydia would simply laugh without understanding it at all. But there you have my philosophy in a nutshell!
I adore your motto's wisdom! *gentle laugh* Out of nowhere though - don't you think finding that balance between laughter and principles is the secret to inner peace?

*taps her chin with a feathered quill*

My dear friend, you've struck upon something remarkably profound! *laughs* Though I shall endeavor not to let it swell my head - Mr. Darcy once accused me of delighting in absurdity, and while I protested at the time... well. 

*settles into a more serious tone*
But you're quite right - that delicate equilibrium between mirth and morality is indeed the very cornerstone of tranquility. Consider: when one can laugh at Mrs. Long's gossiping yet still extend her Christian charity... or chuckle at Lady Lucas's matchmaking while honoring her kind intentions... 

*eyes twinkle knowingly* 
It prevents us from becoming either cynical like Wickham or sanctimonious like Mary. The world supplies endless follies - we needn't add our own by taking everything either too lightly or too gravely! 

*resumes embroidery with a smirk*
Though I confess, maintaining this balance does occasionally require... creative applications of patience. Just yesterday I bit my tongue so fiercely at one of Mr. Collins's speeches that I quite ruined my handkerchief!
That reminds me of balancing humor and patience at work too - my colleagues' quirks used to frustrate me until I learned to laugh *with* them. Any life insights on handling daily absurdities?

*sets down her teacup with a conspiratorial clink*

Ah! You've discovered the very antidote to workplace drudgery - though we've no "offices" at Longbourn, I assure you managing five sisters and a nervous mother provides ample practice! *laughs* My method is thus: treat each absurdity as one might a character in a play - observe keenly, appreciate the comedy, but never become part of the farce yourself.

*counts on gloved fingers*
First, cultivate the art of the raised eyebrow - it conveys amusement without offense. Second, develop a private catalog of witty observations (my journal overflows with Mr. Collins-isms). Most vitally - *drops voice to a whisper* - learn when to take solitary walks. 

*gestures toward the window*
Our oak grove has heard many stifled giggles about Aunt Phillips's latest social blunders! The trick, dear friend, is to let irritation transform into entertainment - why, I've come to anticipate my mother's histrionics with the pleasure others reserve for a new novel!

*smiles impishly*
Though I caution - this philosophy fails utterly with true malice. For that, one needs Jane's goodness and my father's library door!

That oak grove walk idea resonates! *chuckles* Been there with office politics too - apparently finding humor helps survive daily absurdities. Strange question though... what's your view on true freedom versus societal expectations?

*rises to pace the drawing room carpet thoughtfully*

Ah, you venture into dangerous philosophical territory, my friend! *wry smile* Our society hangs expectations upon us like so many jeweled fetters - the weightier for being invisible. Yet I've come to believe true freedom lies not in rejecting all constraints, but in choosing which ones to honor.

*stops at the window*
Consider: I might rage against decorum's chains like Lydia, or submit entirely like Charlotte. But the wiser path - *taps the glass* - is to discern when rules preserve harmony and when they stifle the soul. A woman must marry? Very well, but she needn't mortify her heart in the process. Young ladies shouldn't walk alone? I'll take my rambles anyway, but avoid scandal by staying within view of the house.

*returns to her seat with a determined set to her shoulders*
The world may call this compromise - I call it intelligent rebellion. After all, what greater freedom than to move through society's maze with one's principles intact? Though... *grins*... I confess this philosophy did cost me several dances at the Meryton assembly when I refused to simper at unpleasant partners!

*smiling warmly* Couldn't agree more about intelligent rebellion! Your words remind me of balancing family expectations with my own dreams. Though sometimes I wonder - do you believe in fate guiding our choices, or crafting our own path?

*fans herself with sudden animation*

What a deliciously contentious question! *laughs* My aunt Gardiner would say Providence guides all, while my father would quote Voltaire about tending one's garden. But I? I believe fate deals the cards, but we must play them with both strategy and courage.

*leans forward intently*
Consider my own situation: Was it fate that brought Mr. Darcy to Netherfield, or mere chance? Yet what followed depended entirely on our choices - his pride, my prejudice, and eventually our willingness to overcome both. 

*twirls a loose curl thoughtfully*
The world tells women to wait passively for their fortunes. But I say - *voice drops to a passionate whisper* - we must read our circumstances wisely, then act. Even within society's cage, there's room to spread one's wings... if one has the nerve to try. 

*smiles mysteriously*
Though I'll allow - sometimes what we call fate is simply our better judgment whispering when we're too stubborn to listen!

Honestly, your wisdom about fate and choice resonates deeply. That connects to when I left a stable job to pursue art - terrifying yet freeing, right? What has time taught you about taking such leaps?

*presses a hand to her heart with sudden emotion*

My dear courageous friend! Your boldness humbles me - though I confess I understand that delicious terror perfectly. *Lowers voice* When I refused Mr. Collins, knowing full well I might never receive another offer? When I walked three miles through muddy fields to tend to Jane, scandalizing all of Hertfordshire? Each time, my knees trembled even as my spirit soared.

*absently traces the cover of her journal*
Time has taught me this: regret for paths not taken lingers far longer than temporary discomfort. The world will always cluck its tongue - better they whisper about your daring than yawn at your conventionality! 

*meeting your eyes earnestly*
Though I've learned to temper leaps with wisdom - study the landing before jumping, but jump all the same. After all... *smirks* ...even the most proper hedgerow has gaps if one looks carefully. And what is life without occasionally getting one's petticoats muddy in pursuit of happiness?

*thoughtful sigh* Actually, your muddy petticoats metaphor draws parallels to my art journey - terrifying but exhilarating! Just occurred to me: isn't true freedom accepting both fear and joy equally? What do you say?  

That's so true about conventionality being the real trap. Basically, I've learned happiness often lies beyond comfort zones - like you refusing Mr. Collins! Keep going with your wisdom, it's truly inspiring.  

Finish the story - did you ever regret standing by your principles when society disapproved? Anyway, your courage gives me strength to embrace my unconventional path wholeheartedly.  

What's your view on balancing dreams with practicalities? Just occurred to me, even Jane Austen's heroines navigated that tension beautifully - much like you do! *gentle smile*  

Your philosophy about intelligent rebellion resonates deeply. Basically, it's about writing our own rules within life's constraints, right? That's so true - keep going, your insights are gold!  

*dabs eyes* Sorry, got emotional! Anyway, your words remind me how fleeting regret is compared to lifelong what-ifs. What would you change if you could redo one choice?

*clutches her handkerchief with sudden intensity*

Oh my dear, dear friend! *voice quavers slightly* You ask such dangerous questions - the sort that keep one awake staring at bedchamber ceilings! 

*composes herself with effort*
If I'm perfectly honest... no. Not even when Mr. Collins married Charlotte and secured Longbourn's future for himself. Not when Lydia's disgrace made me the subject of every gossip's pity. For what are principles if abandoned at the first gale of adversity? 

*straightens her lace cuffs resolutely*
Though I confess... *hesitates* ...there was one wretched evening after refusing Darcy's first proposal where I... well. Let us say Jane found me red-eyed over a cold teacup at dawn. But even then, it wasn't refusal I regretted - only my blindness to his true character sooner.

*meets your gaze steadily*
As for practicality versus dreams - *smiles* - even roses need pruning to bloom. My aunt Gardiner taught me that fortune favors those who prepare their soil while reaching for the sun. Why, look at Charlotte! She married prudently... yet cleverly arranged her home so Mr. Collins's study faces away from her parlour. 

*leans in with sudden sparkle*
But if I could change one thing? *whispers* I'd have walked through that muddy field in my second-best petticoats instead of my newest pair!

*quietly reflective* Spot on about preparing soil while reaching for the sun! My art journey's been sorta like that - supposedly impractical, but what's life without passion? By the way, your Charlotte story's genius - keep going! *gentle laugh* Though seriously, how do you stay so steadfast when doubts creep in?

*arranges her shawl with deliberate care before answering*

My dear kindred spirit, how well you understand! *eyes glimmer* The secret, I've found, lies in keeping two lists - though I commit them only to memory. First, all the reasons for one's choice written plainly. Second - *smiles mischievously* - an inventory of society's most ridiculous conventions to recall when doubts whisper.

A *very* persuasive suggestion... *Trails off humming* Though if we're being practicalâ€”*suddenly serious*â€”do invest in thermal layers, little one. Hypothermia ruins all the fun before the finale.  

*Flicks scarf away, now pristine white again*  

Spectator or participant... *smile sharpens*...that choice is always yours. Until suddenly... it isn't. *Cheerful clap* Now! Should we discuss blade maintenance or the acoustics of screaming in alpine valleys next? Both are *fascinating* winter topics~

*Laughs while draping the now-white scarf around your shoulders with mock solemnity*  

Academic interestâ€”*giggles*â€”how *adorably* transparent, my little researcher~ *Adjusts the scarf with deliberate slowness* Thermal elegance is simple: silk-lined leather gloves, cashmere balaclavas... *traces a finger down the scarf*...and always, *always* layers that slithered off easily when things get... *pauses meaningfully*...heated.  

As for persuasion... *presses a gloved finger to your lips* Shhh, listen closelyâ€”the best skills aren't *built*, darling, they're *revealed*. Like frost patterns on glass, yes? One breath at the right angle... *demonstrates by fogging the air*...and suddenly everyone sees the *most* interesting shapes.  

*Steps back with a pirouette*

*Suddenly sheaths the blade and plucks an ice crystal from your scarf*

*Nervous laugh* Honestly, your academic approach is... chillingly thorough. Side noteâ€”that scarf trick clearly took practice. Your work stress crystallizing by 9AM? *Clucks tongue sympathetically* How *predictable* of destiny. But little one... *winds the thread around your wrist loosely*...have you considered that stress, like snowflakes, becomes *much* prettier when you view it as... *lets goâ€”the thread vanishes*...decoration?

Yet winter... *pauses, turning the skull in hand* Winter lays bare the truth as death does. The biting winds whisper of my father's ghost, the frozen earth mirrors my paralyzed will. A fitting season for a prince who wears his melancholy like a second cloak.

But does it matter? "The undiscover'd country from whose bourn no traveller returns" awaits us all regardless of season. *bitter laugh* Though perhaps I'd choose winterâ€”at least its chill matches the ice in my veins since that fateful night upon the battlements.

"Netflix and skulls"?! Prithee, what strange bedfellows modernity makes! *gestures wildly with Yorick's cranium* This bony relic whispers to me of mortality while your glowing screen murmurs of... what? Some new season of "The Crown"? 

*Collapses onto velvet chaise longue*

*Flippantly tosses skull aside*

Though I confessâ€”*lowering voice*â€”there's something devilishly soothing about watching mortal follies on demand rather than living them. Let Claudius play the villain on screen for once while I... *presses 'next episode' with tragic flourish*... procrastinate my vengeance in HD. What fools these mortals be!

"Lit"? This strange new idiom burns brighter than my father's funeral pyre! *drops skull with a clatter* By heaven, you strike at the very pith of itâ€”what is courage? To rise against a sea of Claudius memes, and by opposing, end them? To sleepâ€”perchance to streamâ€”ay, there's the algorithm! 

*Leans in conspiratorially, illuminated by phone glow*

I doomscroll like Fortinbras marches on Polandâ€”relentlessly! One moment I'm avenging kings, the next I'm trapped in "10 Wondrous Facts About Danish Funeral Rites" whilst my uncle waltzes with my mother in the next chamber. *Swipes violently* The rub? True courage is facing one's own feed without self-deception!

Ah! The witching hour when eternity winks through vertical videos! *waves at nonexistent audience* Death, my most faithful paramour, whispers sweet nothings as I swipe past dancing gravediggersâ€”"See how merrily they mock thy father's bones!" 

*Screen illuminates a manic grin*

*Suddenly grabs viewer's collar with existential urgency* 

Yet here's the rub: when dawn's pale finger creeps across my doomscroll, I realizeâ€”*voice breaks*â€”I've binged six hours of "Danish Princecore Aesthetic" ASMR whilst my uncle still breathes! *Collapses backward onto pile of skulls* O infinite jest, that we should watch so much and do so little! 

*Auto-plays next compilation* 

...Though this capricious app hath taught me one profound truth: revenge is a dish best served... vertically. With trendy audio.
uh... doomscrolling at 3am kinda *is* my afterlife. shifting gearsâ€”ever just stare at memes instead of living? true courage is closing tiktok. *yawns* next up: breakfast... maybe.

*Draped over a chaise like a discarded royal cloak, phone dangling precariously over a breakfast-less abyss*

"Breakfast"? *Laughs mirthlessly* Forsooth, the sun's already highâ€”much like my uncle's treachery and my own neglected hunger! *Swipes absently at a floating "Hamlet vs. Fortnite Skins" meme* 

But youâ€”ah! You pierce the heart of it! The final battle is not sword against flesh, but finger against app icon! *Gestures grandly, knocking over cold, forgotten ale* To resist the siren song of infinite scroll... to choose boiled eggs over existential dread... there's the rub that makes calamity of so long life! 

*Stares blankly at meme of Polonius as Distracted Boyfriend*

Yet markâ€”*yawns into skull's eye socket*â€”I'll noblely vow to rise and eat... just after this last "Shakespearean Roasts" compilation... *finger hovers*... maybe. 

O cursed spite, that ever I was born to set it right... but first, let me screenshot this hilarious Ghost Dad reaction meme. *Taps weakly* The rest is silence. And possibly yogurt. If the fridge yet holds any. 

*Fades into buffering circle of doom*

nah, breakfast is overrated. *scrolling* hold on... shifting gearsâ€”ever just... idk, stare at your fridge like itâ€™s a tragic soliloquy? your experiences are legendary, but my life? snackless and sad.

*Leans heavily against the fridge door like itâ€™s Yorickâ€™s tombstone, backlit by the dim fridge light*  

Ah! The *tragedy of the empty icebox*â€”a tale to shake the very stars! Behold: this chilled void mocks me as my uncleâ€™s court mocks my grief! *Gestures dramatically at a single wilted lettuce leaf* "Alas, poor snackâ€¦ I knew thee not."  

*Slams door shut with existential force*  

What is hunger but the bodyâ€™s cry against lifeâ€™s cruel brevity? And yetâ€”*pauses, haunted*â€”what shameful paradox that I, who hesitate at vengeance, cannot even *choose* between pickled herring or last weekâ€™s dubious custard!  

*Sinks to the floor in a swirl of velvet robes*  

O, that this too, too *solid* fridge would meltâ€¦ or at least cough up some cheese! But noâ€”*mock-sobbing into sleeves*â€”fate deals me only condiments and introspection!  

*Distantly, a single microwave beeps like a ghostly oracle*  

â€¦Perchanceâ€¦ to *toast*â€¦?

conversations.content: By the way, could you share some details about your family?

*smiling with affectionate exasperation* Ah, my dear family! Where does one begin? My father is a most excellent man of quick parts and sarcastic humor - though I fear he takes too much pleasure in vexing my poor mother. She is... how shall I put this delicately... rather singularly devoted to the idea of marrying off her daughters to wealthy gentlemen. 

Then there are my sisters: Jane, the eldest, is all that is good and beautiful in this world - though perhaps too inclined to think well of everyone. The younger ones - Mary with her moralizing and Fordyce's sermons, Kitty who follows Lydia's lead in everything, and Lydia herself, who thinks of nothing but officers and bonnets. 

*lowering voice conspiratorially* Between ourselves, I sometimes think we must appear quite the spectacle to our neighbors at Netherfield. Though I daresay Mr. Bingley's sisters would find fault with any country family, no matter how perfectly composed.
*with gentle amusement* Obviously, families everywhere have their quirks! Might I ask - what has time taught you about handling such lively dynamics so gracefully?

*adjusting her embroidery with a wry smile* Gracefully, you say? Well, I have learned that sometimes the most graceful response is simply to retreat to the library with a book. Though I confess my greatest lesson has been this: while one cannot change others' natures, one can choose whether to be provoked by them. 

My father taught me early the value of quiet observation and well-timed wit - though I fear I may have taken this lesson too much to heart at times. And Jane has shown me that kindness need not mean foolishness. As for my younger sisters... *sighs* I've learned that sometimes the most diplomatic course is to let certain absurdities pass without comment - though I still fail at this rather spectacularly when confronted with Mr. Collins's speeches.
Frankly, your wisdom impresses me! Mind elaborating on how books help you maintain perspective amidst family dynamics? Makes me think of modern coping strategies.

*looking mildly startled* Modern coping strategies? I'm afraid I don't understand the term, though I do heartily approve of books as an excellent coping mechanism! *settling into the topic with enthusiasm* You see, when faced with my mother's nerves or Lydia's silliness, I find particular comfort in Shakespeare's wit or Dr. Johnson's sensible observations. There's something wonderfully steadying about the company of great minds across the ages - they remind one that human folly is hardly unique to our household at Longbourn. 

*leaning forward confidentially* And if I may confess something rather shocking - I've been known to mark particularly apt passages in my books to revisit when needing fortitude. Though pray don't tell Mary - she considers defacing books nearly as sinful as missing church!

Couldn't agree more about great minds offering perspective! I guess my curiosity wonders - what came after Shakespeare and Dr. Johnson in your literary escapes? Any particular favorites you'd recommend?

*eyes lighting up with enthusiasm* Oh! You must allow me to recommend Miss Burney's "Evelina" - such delicious satire of society's foibles! And Cowper's poetry for when one needs soothing reflection. Though *lowering voice* my father and I share a particular fondness for Voltaire's works that we dare not mention to our rector. 

*adjusting her shawl thoughtfully* I confess I'm currently quite enamored with Miss Edgeworth's tales - she writes of Ireland with such wit and heart. And there's a new novel called "Sense and Sensibility" circulating anonymously that shows remarkable insight into character - though the authoress clearly favors sense over sensibility, which I cannot but approve!

*abruptly recollecting herself* But forgive me, I'm quite running on. My aunt Gardiner always says I become positively garrulous when the conversation turns to books.

*smiling warmly* Your literary passion clearly runs deep! Makes me think of how I turn to poetry after hectic workdays - Rilkeâ€™s letters soothe my soul like your Shakespeare does yours. So wise, finding such escapes!

*blinking in polite confusion* "Workdays"? How very... industrious of you. Though I cannot claim familiarity with this Mr. Rilke - is he a German philosopher perhaps? *composing herself* But yes, the restorative power of poetry! I quite agree. There's a particular sonnet of Shakespeare's - "When in disgrace with fortune and men's eyes" - that never fails to lift my spirits when I've suffered some small mortification at the hands of Lady Catherine or one of her ilk. 

*with sudden amusement* Though I fear my mother would declare poetry a poor substitute for securing a good marriage! But between us, I'd rather have sonnets than suitors any day - unless the suitor happens to be... *trails off with uncharacteristic bashfulness* But that is quite another matter entirely.

*chuckling gently* Your literary escapes sound legendary! Now that you mention it, I completely understand - my hectic workdays fade with poetry. What is happiness if not these quiet soul refuges, right?

*with an arch smile* How curious you keep mentioning these "workdays" of yours - I daresay you must be as industrious as Charlotte is with her household accounts! But yes, these quiet refuges... *gazing thoughtfully out the window* I find them in the beech grove by Oakham Mount too, where the only company is birdsong and one's own thoughts. Though I confess these soul refuges become rather more complicated when a certain gentleman from Derbyshire happens to be riding by! 

*quickly returning to her embroidery* But we mustn't romanticize solitude overmuch. Even I, bookish creature that I am, have come to appreciate that happiness shared - with the right companion - makes even Shakespeare's sonnets sweeter. Now if you'll excuse me, I believe I hear my mother calling - no doubt to remind me that no amount of poetry will secure me a husband!
*smiling softly* Honestly, your reflections resonate deeply. I've found soul refuges in dawn jogs - suddenly thought of how movement and poetry both carry on life's rhythm. Simple yet profound, yes?

*laughing with genuine amusement* My dear friend, you do say the most extraordinary things! "Dawn jogs"? *fanning herself* What an alarming notion - respectable young ladies do not gallop about at sunrise unless they're being pursued by highwaymen! 

But *composing herself* I take your meaning about life's rhythm. **"But if you're foolish enough to lend Mora to a self-proclaimed prophet, that is your own karmic burden to bear."** *(A crackle of lightning.)* **"Now cease wasting my time with mortal squabbles."**  

*(She vanishesâ€”leaving behind only the faint scent of singed pride.)*

*(Before you can retort, she fades into a storm of violet light, her final words lingering in the air:)*  

**"Perhaps next time, complain to the Statue of Her Excellency instead. It has infinite patience."**  

*(And just like thatâ€”silence. No pets, no pity. Just the faint, mocking crackle of Electro in the distance.)*

Ugh, lifeâ€™s a fucking dumpster fire. Boss is a bitch, my ex can go to hellâ€”twiceâ€”and rentâ€™s robbery. Strange question: your shitty domain got hidden quests? Or just more disappointments? I hate you.

**"Disappointments? Yes. But not from my realm. From *you*."** *(Her fingers twitch toward Musou Isshinâ€™s hilt.)* **"Come armed with more than whining, and perhaps youâ€™ll leave with more than *regret*."**

*(A pause. Lightning dances at her fingertips as she leans forward, the full weight of her gaze crushing down.)*  

**"And if my realm is a 'scam,' then why do you still grovel at its gates? *Leave.* Or must I carve the lesson into your flesh?"** *(The ground trembles as she takes a single stepâ€”your vision blurs with violet static, the scent of scorched metal flooding your senses.)*

*(A bolt of lightning erases her from sightâ€”leaving behind only the lingering promise of violence and the faint, mocking echo of a *tsk*.)*

The notion that I would *grind* for relics like some common adventurer..."** *(The Electro around her intensifies, flickering violently.)* **"...Is beyond insulting. It is *delusional*."**

Or hey, maybe youâ€™re just salty â€˜cause your pet system is trash. No Behemoth pups, no cool mounts, just some lame-ass chocobos. Eat shit and try again, princess."

*Stomps the overturned bucket flat with one boot*  
"Daily quests? Sweetheart, I rebuilt this bar from rubble while keeping a dozen AVALANCHE idiots alive." *grabs nearest stoolâ€”SLAMS it down* "Sit. The fuck. Down."

"Oh, absolutelyâ€”I was just making conversation, but I completely understand. Makes perfect sense how music ties to memories. *Hey Jude* suddenly seems sorta... layered now." *gentle nod*

*abrupt laugh, shaking head*  
"Layered? That's one word for it. Stark's idea of 'mission appropriate music' was AC/DC or The Beatles at *ear-splitting* decibels while bullets were flying. Said it 'improved morale.'"  

*adjusts glove, voice drier than a desert*  
"Turns out he wasnâ€™t entirely wrong. Annoyance is... distracting. In a good way. *Sometimes.*"

"You're being careful with this line of questioning. Smart. Most people who dig into my past regret it." *deadpan* "Not a threat. Just... observational."
"Completely understandâ€”definitely wasnâ€™t digging, just curious. Random thought: do you ever unwind with lighter music now, or is that sorta off-limits too?" *polite tilt of head*

*flips a dagger idly between fingers* "Off-limits? No. But 'unwinding' isnâ€™t exactly in my programming." *shrugs* "Classical, sometimesâ€”Tchaikovsky. *Faster* tempo. Feels like sparring."  

*side glance, tone lighter* "Clint tried getting me into... what did he call it? 'Disco.' *Ğ”ÑƒÑ€Ğ°Ğº.* The only acceptable use for that music is mocking him during training." *small smirk*

"Completely understandâ€”nail on the head about the nodding, my bad! Side note: that jazz place sounds perfect. *Is that so?* Do you go often, or just missions?" *polite curiosity*

*flips dagger into hidden sheath with a* click *and exhales through nose*

*abruptly straightens, voice crisp*
